CO., So the girl ventured with the wine te
her father; and the guests found it excel
lent without knowing any thing as to whence
it came.


Henceforward, as often as there was
party invited to the house, Isabel went to
fetch wine in the little frkin from the syn
Hausen.-They did not, however, continue
TO enjoy the benefit of 1t; the neighbours be-
gan to wonder where the poor gentleman
met with such excellent wine; none equal to
it in the country. The father would inform
nobody. nor would Isabel bctray the secret
Uuluckily. just opposite to them lived the
landlord OF the village inn, who dealt as
largely as he couldip adulterated spirits dc,
among others, had also had taste OF the
knights wine; and thought he to himself,
my friend, .ycu mix this with ten times ITS
body of water, and sell it for good wine still
Where the devil can YOU contriNe to get 1t
FROM He resolved to watch: and he fol-
lowed the daughter as she went for it about
the fourteenth time, with her little hrkin to-
wards the kvif IIausen hill lie hid him
self, and saw her come the exact way from
the old cellar, with her firkin quite full,
shortly afterwards. Accordingly, next even
ing, he set out himself, having first rolled in
to little cart one of the largest empty bar
rels he could find, intending to fill it with
the same precious kind of liquor. He
thought it would be easy to convey down bill;
and he made 4 vow to return every night
until the cellar became empty. As he A.
preached the spot where he had marked the
path the day before, the sky sndlenly began
to grow dark and lowering. The wind rose,
and whistled portcntously OF the gathering
rain, which soon fell IN torrents. The temp
est carried him and his hollow tnb i'om one
side Of the road to the olher. NJ last down
the hill he went, and continued to TAIL deep
er and decpcr, until he i.nlly found himself
lodged in the burial vault.


Here there appeared an awful procession
before his eycs--a regular funeral, bier
hung With black. and hi, wife and fonr neigh.
bours, whom he recognized easily enough
by their gait and garments following it,
wake. At this sight he very naturally faint
ed and on recovering some hours afterwards
he still found himself in the dimly lighted
vault and heard right over his head the old
familiar steeple bell ct lilleda strike twelve
Now he knew 1t was the witchinS hour, and
that he was there living under the church
and the burial ground OF the village iii 4
gloomy vaalt. lie was certainly more deat
than alive, and scarcely ventared to breathe
But sec Il mouk now approaching him slow
" down the narrow steps, opens the Naul
door, and in perfect silence puts some mon.
ey in his hand, and then taking him in hi
arms, he laid him down at the foot OF the
mountain.


1t was cold fro ty night. by degree,
the good host came little TO himself, and
crept without either vine or wine casks. as
far as home. 1t struck one just as he reach
cd it, ana found himself 50 unwell that he
found that he must take to his bed. lii the
course Of three days he died, and the money
which he had brought home, given him b.
the ghostly monk, was just sufficient tn dc.
fray his funeral expenses; his wife and foul
neighbours, as.he had seen them, following
him to the grave.

Udi' brcoaM E8cate---ltyeYv ore who
has frequently crossed the ulA ferry IN Sui
Ivan has witnessed, with delight and won
der the mighty rush 0f water y hch passes

few days ago. younH man, il eros S,iHg the

tated into the briny waters: he rose and re-
ceved tremendous blow in the stomach

sion in the water, he got ho,d Of thc'boat.

full articles.article:
CO., So the girl ventured with the wine te
her father; and the guests found it excel
lent without knowing any thing as to whence
it came.


Henceforward, as often as there was
party invited to the house, Isabel went to
fetch wine in the little frkin from the syn
Hausen.-They did not, however, continue
TO enjoy the benefit of 1t; the neighbours be-
gan to wonder where the poor gentleman
met with such excellent wine; none equal to
it in the country. The father would inform
nobody. nor would Isabel bctray the secret
Uuluckily. just opposite to them lived the
landlord OF the village inn, who dealt as
largely as he couldip adulterated spirits dc,
among others, had also had taste OF the
knights wine; and thought he to himself,
my friend, .ycu mix this with ten times ITS
body of water, and sell it for good wine still
Where the devil can YOU contriNe to get 1t
FROM He resolved to watch: and he fol-
lowed the daughter as she went for it about
the fourteenth time, with her little hrkin to-
wards the kvif IIausen hill lie hid him
self, and saw her come the exact way from
the old cellar, with her firkin quite full,
shortly afterwards. Accordingly, next even
ing, he set out himself, having first rolled in
to little cart one of the largest empty bar
rels he could find, intending to fill it with
the same precious kind of liquor. He
thought it would be easy to convey down bill;
and he made 4 vow to return every night
until the cellar became empty. As he A.
preached the spot where he had marked the
path the day before, the sky sndlenly began
to grow dark and lowering. The wind rose,
and whistled portcntously OF the gathering
rain, which soon fell IN torrents. The temp
est carried him and his hollow tnb i'om one
side Of the road to the olher. NJ last down
the hill he went, and continued to TAIL deep
er and decpcr, until he i.nlly found himself
lodged in the burial vault.


Here there appeared an awful procession
before his eycs--a regular funeral, bier
hung With black. and hi, wife and fonr neigh.
bours, whom he recognized easily enough
by their gait and garments following it,
wake. At this sight he very naturally faint
ed and on recovering some hours afterwards
he still found himself in the dimly lighted
vault and heard right over his head the old
familiar steeple bell ct lilleda strike twelve
Now he knew 1t was the witchinS hour, and
that he was there living under the church
and the burial ground OF the village iii 4
gloomy vaalt. lie was certainly more deat
than alive, and scarcely ventared to breathe
But sec Il mouk now approaching him slow
" down the narrow steps, opens the Naul
door, and in perfect silence puts some mon.
ey in his hand, and then taking him in hi
arms, he laid him down at the foot OF the
mountain.


1t was cold fro ty night. by degree,
the good host came little TO himself, and
crept without either vine or wine casks. as
far as home. 1t struck one just as he reach
cd it, ana found himself 50 unwell that he
found that he must take to his bed. lii the
course Of three days he died, and the money
which he had brought home, given him b.
the ghostly monk, was just sufficient tn dc.
fray his funeral expenses; his wife and foul
neighbours, as.he had seen them, following
him to the grave.

EPtTONr

ofimportant events, which Immediately prcced-
ed the American Revolution, ana occurred dur
ng that glorious era in our history.
full articles.article:
.g that glorious era in our history.


[CompileaJo the Boston PqtrioLl
March %. 1765-Stamp Act, passed by
the British Parii ,ment, the first attempt to
tax America, without allowing her repre-
sentation in Parliament.


October--First Congress convened at n.
York. which pCtitioned for the repeal Of the
Stamp Act.


March II, i766-Fhc Stamp Act repeal
ed, reserving, however, a right to make
laws binding on the colonies, in all cases
whatsoever


1767-Duties levied on teas, paper, class,
&c. all OF which, excepting that OH teas,
were repealed in 1863.


Sept. 50, l768--Arrival Of British troops
at Boston from Halifax


March 5, 1770--- Boston Massacre


Dece mber 10, l7I3-Destruction of three
hundred and forty chests of tea, in Boston
harbor, BY a party OF citizens disguised as
Indians.


June l, 1774-Port of Boston closed by act
of Parliament.


Sept. 4, 1774-Second Congress convened
in Philadelphia.


Oct. l774-After drawing up memorial
to the people of England. recommending to



with Great Britain, and advising their con-
stituents to new choice Of delegates, to
meet on the 10th of May, l775, the Congress
dissolved.


April 16, l775-Battle of Lexingt~i, in
which the proyincials lost in killed, wound
ed, and missing, eighty eight; the British
273.


June II, l775-Battlc of Bunker Hill. in
which the Provincial, lost 449; the British.
1853, including 50 officers; and the village of
Charlestown, containing $50 buildings, SET
on fire by order of the British commander.
and entirely construed.


May 10, l775-l icondcroga captured bv
Colonies Ethan Allen, and Benedict Arnold.
May 20---Articlcs Of confederation and
union agreed on by the colonies.


July Washington takes command Of the
Provincial army.


Dec.-Quebec hesiegcd b. Arnold and
Montgomery, who had previously conquered!
Montreal In fruitlcss attempt to taSe
that city by escalade, Montgomery wa,
slain Dec. 81


l776. March 4-Derchcster Heights for
tifed by Washington during the night.


March 17-Boston evacuated by the Brit
ish.


June 29-Thc British squadron under
Dir feter farKer, attacked sullivan ) Island
in Charleston harbor, 5. c. and were repuls-
ed with the loss of more than 200; the 4
mercahs only lost So.


July 4-Declaration OF Independence by
Congress.


July 12--Lord Howe arrived a. Staten
Island from Europe, With formidable
squadron, and thirty thousand men, chiefly
Hessians.


Aug 23- Lord Fl. landed, with hisbrother
Sir William, and 44,0o0 troops at Long ISL
ard.


Aug. 2s-Battle of Long Island, in which
the Americans were beaten, with the loss OF
one thousand men, and Lord Sterling and
General Sullivan captured; British and Hes
sian loss, $50,

ish King 70 be Free. Sovereign, and In
dependent.


1785-Sweeden and Denmark acknowi-
edged the Independence oi the United states
in February, Span in March, aud Russia IN
July.


Sept. 3-Defnitive Treaty of Peace sign
ed at Paris, by David Hartley on the part
OF Britain; and by Benz. Franklin, John Jay,
and John Adams on the part OF the United
States.

the peasants confessed their sins to him.
commanded them TO do penancc by planting
some sets of the olive, the vine, and other
kinds Of trees; the soil, which before was
dry and destitute of vegetation, has since be.
come very productive. This is one Of Tie
best things that ever came from cati5,i.
